defs.docs: Stylist is a CSS-in-Rust styling solution for WebAssembly Applications.

attributes.value: / Stylist is a CSS-in-Rust styling solution for WebAssembly Applications.
/ To enable yew integration. Enable feature `yew_integration` in `Cargo.toml`.
/ You can create a style and use it with yew like this:
/ To create a stylesheet, you can use [`style!`]:
/ If you want to parse a string into a style at runtime, you can use [`Style::new`]:
/ Any struct that implements [`YieldStyle`] trait can call
/ Everything that is not in a conditioned block will be applied to the Component
/ the class of this style is applied to.
/ You may also use Current Selector (`&`) in CSS selectors to denote the container element:
/ You can also use other CSS rules(such as: keyframes, supports and media):
/ - `macros`: Enabled by default, this flag enables procedural macro support.
/ - `random`: Enabled by default, this flag uses `fastrand` crate to generate a random
/   class name. Disabling this flag will opt for a class name that is counter-based.
/ - `yew_integration`: This flag enables yew integration, which implements [`Classes`](::yew::html::Classes) for
/   [`Style`] and provides a [`Global`](yew::Global) component for applying global styles.

defs.name: manager
defs.docs: Customise behaviour of Styles.

attributes.value: / This module contains [`StyleManager`] which can be used for customising
/ mounting point / mounting behaviour for styles (when rendering contents into a `ShadowRoot` or an `<iframe />`).
/ This is an advanced feature and most of the time you don't need to use it.

defs.name: ast
defs.docs: This module contains the semantic representation of a CSS StyleSheet.

attributes.value: / This module contains the semantic representation of a CSS StyleSheet.
/ This module is not stable at the moment and is exposed to be used by procedural macros.
/ Its API may change at anytime.

defs.name: GlobalStyle
defs.docs: A struct that represents a global Style.

attributes.value: / A struct that represents a global Style.
/ This class is equivalent to [`Style`](crate::Style) but for global styles.
/ It will replace Current Selectors (`&`) with `:root` and apply dangling style attributes to
/ the root element (`html` when style is not applied in a Shadow DOM).

defs.name: Style
defs.docs: A struct that represents a scoped Style.

attributes.value: / A struct that represents a scoped Style.
/ # Style Scoping and Substitution Rule for Current Selector(`&`):
/ Currently, Stylist processes selectors with the following rules:
/ If a style attribute is not in any block (dangling style attribute), it will be scoped with
/   the generated class name. (Applied to the element where the generated class name is applied
/   For example, for the following style:
/   Stylist will generate the following stylesheet:
/ For style attributes that are in a block, for each selector of that block, the following rules
/ - If a selector contains a Current Selector(`&`), the current selector will be substituted with
/ - If a selector starts with a pseudo-class selector, it will be applied to the root element.
/ - For other selectors, it will be prefixed with the generated class name.
/   Root pseudo class (`:root`) will also be treated like a Current Selector.

A struct that can be used as a source to create a [`Style`](crate::Style) or

attributes.value: / A struct that can be used as a source to create a [`Style`](crate::Style) or
/ This struct is usually created by [`css!`](crate::css) macro.
/ You can also get a StyleSource instance from a string or a [`Sheet`] by calling `.into()`.

defs.name: YieldStyle
defs.docs: A trait to create [`Style`].

attributes.value: / Any struct that implements this trait can call [`self.style()`](YieldStyle::style) to get a style class.
/ You can use this to achieve dynamic theming.

defs.name: macros
defs.docs: This module contains runtime support for the macros and documents their usage.

attributes.value: / This module contains runtime support for the macros and documents their usage.
/ There are two syntaxes available: [string literal] and [inline].
/ This syntax is simliar to the [`format!`] macro from the standard library.
/ The first argument of this syntax is a string literal followed by an argument list. This macro
/ will replace `${arg}` with the argument in the argument list when creating the AST.
/ This syntax supports interpolation on values of style attributes, selectors, `@supports` and `@media` rules.
/ Interpolated strings are denoted with `${ident}` and any type that implements [`Display`] can be
/ used as value. Only named argument are supported at this moment.
/ If you do need to print a `${` sequence, you may use `$${` to escape to a `${`.
/ `$${` escape can only present where `${` is valid in the css stylesheet.
/ let style = Style::new(s).expect("Failed to create style");
/ You may also directly inline a stylesheet in the macro.
/ Like in string interpolation syntax, interpolated values are allowed in most places through the `${expr}`
/ syntax. In distinction, the braces contain a rust expression of any type implementing [`Display`]
/ will be evaluated in the surrounding context.
/ Due to the tokenizer of the Rust complier, there are some quirks with literals. For example, `4em` would be
/ tokenized as a floating point literal with a missing exponent and a suffix of `m`. To work around this issue, use
/ string interpolation as in `${"4em"}`. Similarly, some color hash-tokens like `#44444e` as misinterpreted,
/ The stable Rust tokenizer also currently offers no way to inspect whitespace between tokens, as tracked in
/ [the Span inspection API issue](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/54725). This means that, e.g. the two
/ selectors `.class-a.class-b` and `.class-a .class-b` can not be differentiated. **The macro errs on side of the
/ former input without any spaces.** If you meant to write the latter, use `.class-a *.class-b`.
/ To be more specific, a space is inserted between two tokens `L R` iff (regardless of the space being present in the macro input):
/ - `L` is either a closing bracket `)}]`, an identifier `red`, a literal string `"\e600"` or number `3px`, or the '*' character.
/ - `R` is either an identifier, a literal string or number, the '*' or '#' character.
/ Spacing around interpolation is ignored regardless.
/ Be aware that the above is subject to change once the Span API is stabilized. To avoid future rewriting, use spacing
/ in your source code that follows the same rules. Refer to the associated [bug report](https://github.com/futursolo/stylist-rs/issues/41)
/ to discuss this limitation and offer additional suggestions
/ This syntax provides more precise error locations and advanced diagnostics information.
/ let style = Style::new(s).expect("Failed to create style");
/ Stylist currently does not check or escape the content of interpolated strings. It is possible
/ to pass invalid strings that would result in an invalid stylesheet. In debug mode, if feature `parser` is
/ enabled, Stylist will attempt to parse the stylesheet again after interpolated strings are
/ substituted with its actual value to check if the final stylesheet is valid.
